subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: IMHO As a southern England English speaker I pronounce Air and Ear one way (and very similar to the way KR pronounced them).  Others from across the Atlantic
messageBody:
IMHO

As a southern England English speaker I pronounce Air and Ear one way (and very similar to the way KR pronounced them).  Others from across the Atlantic pronounce them another way.  Our cousins in South Africa and Australia other ways again.  And so
on throughout the English speaking world.  We all understand the sounds that we see written and we hear them in our own voice.

From this point of view, I am wholly at one with KR in his use of "words" to describe the sounds of the different glyphs.  It allows all of us
to use our own language to interpret the written word.

Just becuase one regional accent does not distinguish between certain vowels which other regional accents do, does not make either one 
right or wrong.

Moira 

On 31/10/2007, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
Anthony Grahn wrote:
>
>
> Maybe for the benefit of beginners and our own discourse, we should
> post a rough IPA mapping right away maybe with the caveat that the
> characters are actually phonemic (ie each character represents a suite
> of sounds of which the one listed is prominent). If mine is an
> acceptable first pass then let's put it up and if it's way off then
> someone please let me know so I can correct myself.
> In building such a rough map I would have two humble suggestions:
> 1. That Kingsley Read was intelligent and well informed thus, at least
> to him if not me, the examples in QM are consistent.
> 2. That Read was using a accent widely distributed in the middle
> 20th century. He refers to "the majority of English speakers" and
> while today I suspect "the" American accent is now that of the
> majority, I intuit Read was effectively referring to BBC English. He
> also refers to "George V" but crawling over tapes of him to find how
> he pronounced "j'ai" is impractical (and a personal anathema to a
> native son of George Washington's country ;-) while flipping through
> the Oxford unabridged to look up 40 words is pretty simple.
>
> After this is done, maybe we could put up multiple example sounds of
> each letter from several accents which clearly state the speakers
> origin and note when a particular accent does not use a particular
> sound (group). This latter step would probably be very useful to
> beginners with only a cursory knowledge of linguistics who want to get
> up and running quickly or people whose agenda may not require highly
> detailed knowledge of pronunciation. But I think we need at least an
> agreement on a rough IPA map before we could venture toward examples.
>

This sounds like a great idea. Let me upload my first attempt at this, a
chart called revised_with_ipa.png, on the main section of the files
page. The shapes of my letters are all wrong in this chart, so ignore
that. That is one reason I haven't posted it.

In addition, in the future we could post sounds that can be opened and
played in a browser window. That requires more time than either of us
have right now, but I'm putting it out there as a possiblity.

Paul



--
